intro: Brassica willdenovii, commonly known as wild mustard, is a herbaceous annual plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes other well-known plants like cabbage and broccoli. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–100 cm, featuring alternate, pinnately lobed leaves and small, yellow flowers arranged in racemes. Its seeds are small, angular, and often contain glucosinolates, which are defensive compounds common in the Brassicaceae family. Brassica willdenovii is often found in disturbed soils and can be a weed in agricultural settings.
